intro: Azorella prolifera var. hirsuta, commonly known as the hairy azorella, is a member of the Apiaceae family and is native to the high Andes of South America. This perennial plant is characterized by its dense, mat-forming growth habit and produces small, white to pale yellow flowers. Its leaves are typically hairy, giving it its common name, and it thrives in cold, arid environments. The plant has adapted to harsh conditions through its extensive root system and ability to store water. It plays an important ecological role in stabilizing soil in its native habitat.
